appeals.title: Appeals and Miscellaneous Provisions
appeals.content: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Board may appeal to the High Court. The Act also contains provisions for protection of action taken in good faith, delegation of powers, and other miscellaneous matters.
appeals.bareActText:
29. Any person aggrieved by an order made by the Board under this Act may prefer an appeal to the High Court within sixty days from the date on which the order is communicated to such person.

30. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Central Government, the Board, or any officer of the Central Government or any member, officer or other employee of the Board for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Act or any rule or order made thereunder.

31. The Central Government may, by notification, delegate such of its powers under this Act as it may deem necessary to any officer or authority subordinate to it.

32. If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order published in the Official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as may appear to it to be necessary or expedient for removing the difficulty.

34. The Central Government may, by notification, make rules for carrying out the provisions of this Act.

35. Every rule made under this Act shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before each House of Parliament, while it is in session, for a total period of thirty days which may be comprised in one session or in two or more successive sessions, and if, before the expiry of the session immediately following the session or the successive sessions aforesaid, both Houses agree in making any modification in the rule or both Houses agree that the rule should not be made, the rule shall thereafter have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be.

36. If any provision of this Act is held to be unconstitutional or invalid, the remainder of this Act shall remain in force.

37. The Central Government may, by notification, remove any difficulty that arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act.

38. Nothing in this Act shall affect the provisions of the Right to Information Act, 2005.

39. The provisions of this Act shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, the provisions of any other law for the time being in force.

40. The Central Government may, by notification, exempt any class of Data Fiduciaries from the application of any of the provisions of this Act for such period and subject to such conditions as may be specified in the notification.

41. The Central Government may, by notification, make rules to provide for the manner in which personal data may be transferred outside India.

42. The Central Government may, by notification, make rules to provide for the manner in which consent may be obtained and managed.

43. The Central Government may, by notification, make rules to provide for the manner in which data breaches shall be notified.

44. This Act may be called the Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023.
appeals.laymanExplanation: This section covers appeals and other important provisions: (1) Appeals - If you disagree with a Board decision, you can appeal to the High Court within 60 days. (2) Protection - Government and Board officials are protected from lawsuits if they act in good faith. (3) Delegation - The government can delegate powers to other officers. (4) Removing difficulties - The government can make orders to resolve implementation issues. (5) Parliamentary oversight - Rules must be presented to Parliament. (6) Relationship with other laws - This Act works alongside other laws like RTI Act. (7) Exemptions - The government can exempt certain entities. (8) Rules - The government can make detailed rules for transfers, consent, and breach notifications.

subsections.content: Any person aggrieved by an order of the Board may appeal to the High Court within sixty days.
subsections.bareActText: 29. Any person aggrieved by an order made by the Board under this Act may prefer an appeal to the High Court within sixty days from the date on which the order is communicated to such person.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If you disagree with a decision made by the Data Protection Board, you can appeal to the High Court. You must file the appeal within 60 days of receiving the Board's decision. This gives you a way to challenge Board decisions if you think they're wrong.
subsections.crossMapping: GDPR Article 78: Data subjects have right to effective judicial remedy against supervisory authority decisions. Key Similarity: Both provide for appeals to courts.
citations: Section 29, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

subsections.title: Protection of Action Taken in Good Faith - Section 30
subsections.content: No legal proceeding shall lie against government or Board officials for actions taken in good faith.
subsections.bareActText: 30. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Central Government, the Board, or any officer of the Central Government or any member, officer or other employee of the Board for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Act or any rule or order made thereunder.
subsections.laymanExplanation: Government and Board officials are protected from lawsuits if they act in good faith (honestly and with good intentions) while doing their jobs under this Act. This protects them from being sued for doing their duty, as long as they act honestly and reasonably.
subsections.crossMapping: Common Legal Principle: Similar protection exists in many administrative law frameworks. Key Similarity: Protects officials acting in good faith.
citations: Section 30, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

subsections.title: Delegation of Powers - Section 31
subsections.content: The Central Government may delegate its powers to subordinate officers or authorities.
subsections.bareActText: 31. The Central Government may, by notification, delegate such of its powers under this Act as it may deem necessary to any officer or authority subordinate to it.
subsections.laymanExplanation: The government can give some of its powers under this Act to other government officers or departments. This allows the government to distribute work and make implementation more efficient.
subsections.crossMapping: Common Administrative Law Principle: Similar delegation provisions exist in many laws. Key Similarity: Allows efficient administration through delegation.
citations: Section 31, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

subsections.title: Removal of Difficulties - Section 32
subsections.content: The Central Government may make orders to remove difficulties in implementing the Act.
subsections.bareActText: 32. If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order published in the Official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as may appear to it to be necessary or expedient for removing the difficulty.
subsections.laymanExplanation: If there are problems implementing the Act, the government can make orders to fix those problems. This gives flexibility to resolve issues that come up during implementation.
subsections.crossMapping: Common Legislative Provision: Many laws have similar 'removal of difficulties' clauses. Key Similarity: Provides flexibility for implementation.
citations: Section 32, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023

subsections.title: Relationship with Other Laws - Sections 38-39
subsections.content: This Act works alongside other laws and does not affect the Right to Information Act, 2005.
subsections.bareActText:
38. Nothing in this Act shall affect the provisions of the Right to Information Act, 2005.

39. The provisions of this Act shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, the provisions of any other law for the time being in force.
subsections.laymanExplanation: This Act works together with other laws. It doesn't replace or cancel out other laws like the Right to Information Act. If there are other laws that apply, this Act adds to them, it doesn't take away from them. This ensures all laws work together.
subsections.crossMapping: Common Legal Principle: Most laws specify their relationship with other laws. Key Similarity: Ensures laws work together rather than conflict.
